trans-unit.source: Configure Active Directory for Azure RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: Configure Active Directory for Azure RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: Learn how to set up Active Directory to work with Azure RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to set up Active Directory to work with Azure RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Active Directory for Azure RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: Configuring Active Directory for Azure RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: For a hybrid collection of Azure RemoteApp, you need to set up an Active Directory domain infrastructure on-premises and an Azure Active Directory tenant with Directory Integration (and optionally single sign-on).
trans-unit.target: For a hybrid collection of Azure RemoteApp, you need to set up an Active Directory domain infrastructure on-premises and an Azure Active Directory tenant with Directory Integration (and optionally single sign-on).

trans-unit.source: Additionally, you need to create some Active Directory objects in the on-premises directory.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, you need to create some Active Directory objects in the on-premises directory.

trans-unit.source: Use the following information to configure the on-premises Active Directory and Azure AD, and then integrate the two.
trans-unit.target: Use the following information to configure the on-premises Active Directory and Azure AD, and then integrate the two.

trans-unit.source: Configure your on-premises Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Configure your on-premises Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Start by configuring your on-premises Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Start by configuring your on-premises Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: You need to identify the UPN domain suffix to use, and then create Active Directory objects for RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: You need to identify the UPN domain suffix to use, and then create Active Directory objects for RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Haven’t added Active Directory Domain Services to your Windows Server 2012 R2 environment yet?
trans-unit.target: Haven’t added Active Directory Domain Services to your Windows Server 2012 R2 environment yet?

trans-unit.source: Check out [these instructions](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc731053.aspx) for information on how to do just that.
trans-unit.target: Check out [these instructions](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc731053.aspx) for information on how to do just that.

trans-unit.source: Examine and configure the UPN domain suffix
trans-unit.target: Examine and configure the UPN domain suffix

trans-unit.source: If your forest is not configured with a UPN suffix that matches the Azure AD domain that you will use for RemoteApp, you need to add it.
trans-unit.target: If your forest is not configured with a UPN suffix that matches the Azure AD domain that you will use for RemoteApp, you need to add it.

trans-unit.source: Determine if the necessary suffix is configured:
trans-unit.target: Determine if the necessary suffix is configured:

trans-unit.source: Launch Active Directory Users and Computers.
trans-unit.target: Launch Active Directory Users and Computers.

trans-unit.source: Expand the domain name, and then click **Users**.
trans-unit.target: Expand the domain name, and then click **Users**.

trans-unit.source: Right-click **Administrator**, and then click **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click **Administrator**, and then click **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Account** tab, look at the UPN names configured for this domain in the **User logon name** field.
trans-unit.target: On the **Account** tab, look at the UPN names configured for this domain in the **User logon name** field.

trans-unit.source: If you do not see a suffix that matches the domain name that you want to use for your RemoteApp collection, do the following:
trans-unit.target: If you do not see a suffix that matches the domain name that you want to use for your RemoteApp collection, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Launch Active Directory Domains and Trusts.
trans-unit.target: Launch Active Directory Domains and Trusts.

trans-unit.source: Right-click **Active Directory Domains and Trusts**, and then click **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click **Active Directory Domains and Trusts**, and then click **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: Review the list of suffixes.
trans-unit.target: Review the list of suffixes.

trans-unit.source: Type the FQDN of the domain name in the box, and click **Add**, then **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Type the FQDN of the domain name in the box, and click **Add**, then **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Example: contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: Example: contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: DO NOT include the "@" in the suffix here.
trans-unit.target: DO NOT include the "@" in the suffix here.

trans-unit.source: From now on, when you create new users, you can select the new suffix from User logon name.
trans-unit.target: From now on, when you create new users, you can select the new suffix from User logon name.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, you can change the suffix for existing users on the Account tab in the properties of the users.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, you can change the suffix for existing users on the Account tab in the properties of the users.

trans-unit.source: For more information see [Add User Principal Name Suffixes](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc772007.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information see [Add User Principal Name Suffixes](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc772007.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Create objects for RemoteApp in Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Create objects for RemoteApp in Active Directory

trans-unit.source: RemoteApp needs two objects in your on-premises Active Directory:
trans-unit.target: RemoteApp needs two objects in your on-premises Active Directory:

trans-unit.source: A service account to provide access to domain resources for RemoteApp programs by joining RDSH end points to the on-premises domain.
trans-unit.target: A service account to provide access to domain resources for RemoteApp programs by joining RDSH end points to the on-premises domain.

trans-unit.source: An Organizational Unit (OU) to contain RemoteApp machine objects.
trans-unit.target: An Organizational Unit (OU) to contain RemoteApp machine objects.

trans-unit.source: Use of the OU is recommended (but not required) to isolate the accounts and policies you will use with RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: Use of the OU is recommended (but not required) to isolate the accounts and policies you will use with RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Use the following information to create each of these objects.
trans-unit.target: Use the following information to create each of these objects.

trans-unit.source: Create the service account:
trans-unit.target: Create the service account:

trans-unit.source: Launch Active Directory Users and Computers.
trans-unit.target: Launch Active Directory Users and Computers.

trans-unit.source: Right-click **Users**, and then click **New > User**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click **Users**, and then click **New > User**.

trans-unit.source: Enter a user name and password for the RemoteApp service account.
trans-unit.target: Enter a user name and password for the RemoteApp service account.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** You will need this account information when you create your RemoteApp collection.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** You will need this account information when you create your RemoteApp collection.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Organizational Unit (OU)
trans-unit.target: Create a new Organizational Unit (OU)

trans-unit.source: In Active Directory Users and Computers, right-click your domain.
trans-unit.target: In Active Directory Users and Computers, right-click your domain.

trans-unit.source: Click **New > Organizational Unit**.
trans-unit.target: Click **New > Organizational Unit**.

trans-unit.source: Add the service account you created for RemoteApp to this new OU.
trans-unit.target: Add the service account you created for RemoteApp to this new OU.

trans-unit.source: To do this, find the service account you created.
trans-unit.target: To do this, find the service account you created.

trans-unit.source: Right-click it, and then click **Move**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click it, and then click **Move**.

trans-unit.source: Select the new OU, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Select the new OU, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Grant the RemoteApp service account the authority to add and delete computers to this
trans-unit.target: Grant the RemoteApp service account the authority to add and delete computers to this

trans-unit.source: OU:
trans-unit.target: OU:

trans-unit.source: From the Active Directory Users and Computers snap-in, click **View > Advanced Features**.
trans-unit.target: From the Active Directory Users and Computers snap-in, click **View > Advanced Features**.

trans-unit.source: This adds the **Security** tab to the Properties information.
trans-unit.target: This adds the **Security** tab to the Properties information.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the RemoteApp service OU, and then click **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the RemoteApp service OU, and then click **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Security** tab, click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Security** tab, click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: Select the RemoteApp service account user object, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Select the RemoteApp service account user object, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Advanced**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Advanced**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Permissions** tab, select the RemoteApp service account, and then click **Edit**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Permissions** tab, select the RemoteApp service account, and then click **Edit**.

trans-unit.source: Select **This object and all descendant objects** in the **Applies to** field.
trans-unit.target: Select **This object and all descendant objects** in the **Applies to** field.

trans-unit.source: In the **Permissions** field, select **Allow** next to the Create Computer Objects and Delete Computer Objects, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Permissions** field, select **Allow** next to the Create Computer Objects and Delete Computer Objects, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK** on the remaining two windows.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK** on the remaining two windows.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Now that the on-premises Active Directory is set up, move to Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Now that the on-premises Active Directory is set up, move to Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: You need to create a custom domain that matches the UPN domain suffix for your on-premises domain and set up directory integration.
trans-unit.target: You need to create a custom domain that matches the UPN domain suffix for your on-premises domain and set up directory integration.

trans-unit.source: The hybrid collection supports only Azure Active Directory accounts that have been synced (using a tool like DirSync) from a Windows Server Active Directory deployment; specifically, either synced with the Password Synchronization option or synced with Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) federation configured.
trans-unit.target: The hybrid collection supports only Azure Active Directory accounts that have been synced (using a tool like DirSync) from a Windows Server Active Directory deployment; specifically, either synced with the Password Synchronization option or synced with Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) federation configured.

trans-unit.source: Use the following information to configure Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Use the following information to configure Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: [Add your domain](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh969247.aspx) – Use this information to add a domain that matches the UPN domain suffix of your on-premises Active Directory domain.
trans-unit.target: [Add your domain](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh969247.aspx) – Use this information to add a domain that matches the UPN domain suffix of your on-premises Active Directory domain.

trans-unit.source: [Directory integration](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj573653.aspx) – Use this information to choose a directory integration option – either [DirSync with Password Synchronization](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn441214.aspx) or [DirSync with federation](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn441213.aspx).
trans-unit.target: [Directory integration](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj573653.aspx) – Use this information to choose a directory integration option – either [DirSync with Password Synchronization](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn441214.aspx) or [DirSync with federation](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn441213.aspx).

trans-unit.source: You can also configure [Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn249466.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You can also configure [Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn249466.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Trouble configuring your directory synchronization?
trans-unit.target: Trouble configuring your directory synchronization?

trans-unit.source: If you are having trouble configuring directory synchronization, check the following:
trans-unit.target: If you are having trouble configuring directory synchronization, check the following:

trans-unit.source: You are using the latest version of Azure Directory Sync tool
trans-unit.target: You are using the latest version of Azure Directory Sync tool

trans-unit.source: In the management portal, under **Active Directory->Default Directory->Domains**, you already added your custom domain (e.g mydomain.com) and made it the primary one.
trans-unit.target: In the management portal, under **Active Directory->Default Directory->Domains**, you already added your custom domain (e.g mydomain.com) and made it the primary one.

trans-unit.source: Under **Active Directory->Default Directory->Users**, you add a new user under that domain (e.g. myAzureSyncUser@mydomain.com).
trans-unit.target: Under **Active Directory->Default Directory->Users**, you add a new user under that domain (e.g. myAzureSyncUser@mydomain.com).

trans-unit.source: On your domain in Active Directory, you added a new domain user and made him a member of Enterprise Admins (e.g. myDomainSyncUser@mydomain.com).
trans-unit.target: On your domain in Active Directory, you added a new domain user and made him a member of Enterprise Admins (e.g. myDomainSyncUser@mydomain.com).

trans-unit.source: Now start the Azure Directory Sync tool, and use **myAzureSyncUser@mydomain.com** credentials for the first prompt (Microsoft Azure Active Directory Administrator Credentials) and use **myDomainSyncUser@mydomain.com** for the second prompt.
trans-unit.target: Now start the Azure Directory Sync tool, and use **myAzureSyncUser@mydomain.com** credentials for the first prompt (Microsoft Azure Active Directory Administrator Credentials) and use **myDomainSyncUser@mydomain.com** for the second prompt.
